choices.text: Product of Vd and first order rate constant
Area under the blood concentration Vs Time plot

questions.text: Which of the following pharmacokinetic values most reliably reflects the total amount of drug reaching the systemic target after oral administration?
questions.solution:
Bioavailability is determines by AUC of Cp Vs Time plot

Bioavailability explains the fraction of administered drug dose that reaches the systemic circulation in an unchanged form.

Vd and Total body clearance (Vd X first order rate constant) are important in determining the amount of drug that reaches the target tissue

Only AUC reflects absorption, distribution, metabolism and excretion factors. That is why it is the most reliable and popular method of evaluating bioavailability.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 22-23.

questions.text: All of the following aggravate myasthenia gravis except:
questions.solution:
Drugs that exacerbate myasthenia:

For Amitabh's MCQ remember Beta has BP

Amitabh →Myasthenia gravis

Ami → Aminoglycosides

M → Macrolides, Magnesium

C → Curare, Caine (Local anaesthetics)

Q→ Quinine, Quinidine

Beta → Beta blockers

B → Botulinum toxin

P → Penicillamine

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 121.

choices.text: Thiazides increases tubular reabsorption of lithium
Thiazides acts as add on drug for lithium
Thiazides and lithium both cause tremors

questions.text: A patient on lithium therapy developed hypertension. After being started on thiazides for hypertension, he suffered from coarse tremors and other symptoms suggestive of lithium toxicity. Explain the likely mechanism of this interaction.
questions.solution:
• Majority of sodium reabsorption occurs in proximal convoluted tubule
  • Both sodium (Na+) and Lithium (Li+) carry one electron in their outer shell, which depicts
    • Both can easily obtain a stable configuration of inert gas by losing one electron from their outer shell
    • Both lose their outer shell electrons in reactions to form positive ions with a +1 charge
    • Both have similar physical and chemical properties


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 477.

questions.text: Though rare, a serious toxicity associated with the thioamides is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Rarely, the thioamides cause severe adverse reactions that include agranulocytosis, vasculitis, hepatic damage, and hypoprothrombinemia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 276.

questions.text: A 54-year-old obese patient with type 2 diabetes has a history of alcoholism. In this patient, metformin should either be avoided or used with extreme caution because the combination of metformin and ethanol increases the risk of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Biguanides, especially the older drug phenformin, have been associated with lactic acidosis. Thus, metformin should be avoided or used with extreme caution in patients with conditions that increase the risk of lactic acidosis, including acute ethanol ingestion.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 299.

choices.text: It is a prodrug converted to its active metabolite spontaneously in the blood
It has low lipophilicity and does not cross the placental barrier
It causes a depletion in protein C before it decreases prothrombin
It inhibits release of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors from hepatocytes

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding warfarin is true?
questions.solution:
Warfarin inhibits the hepatic synthesis of factors II (prothrombin), VII, IX, and X. Its onset of anticoagulation activity is slow, and its impact on individual coagulation factors depends on their half-lives. Factor VII and protein C have much shorter half-lives than prothrombin, and so the extrinsic pathway and protein C system are the first to be affected by warfarin. The intrinsic pathway continues to function for 2 to 3 days, causing a state of hypercoagulability and possible vascular thrombosis.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 668.

choices.text: Accumulation of nitroprusside because of its long half-life

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the hospital by ambulance following a car accident causing serious head injuries. His blood pressure is 220/ 170 mm Hg. Funduscopy reveals retinal damage, and you administer nitroprusside via infusion. Control of the hypertension requires 72 hours and you notice the patient becoming increasingly fatigued and nauseous. The mostly likely cause of these symptoms is
questions.solution:
The toxicity of nitroprusside is caused by the release of cyanide and the accumulation of thiocyanate. Hydroxocobalamin is used to reduce the toxicity of nitroprusside through the formation of the less toxic cyanocobalamin.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 544.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in atrial arrhythmias?
questions.solution:
The brevity of the atrial action potential and lack of lidocaine effect on channe recovery due to the relatively rapid dissociation kinetics may explain it's inefficacy in atrial arrhythmias.

  • Supraventricular Arrhythmia :
    • Adenosine
    • Verapamil
    • Diltiazem
    • Digoxin
  • Ventricular arrhythmia :
    • Lidocaine
    • Mexiletene
  • Both :
    • Amiodarone
    • Beta blockers
    • CLass 1a / 1c anti arrhythmics

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 575.

questions.text: The ADR of aminoglycosides is lesser when given at which of the following dosing regimen?
questions.solution:
Aminoglycosides, being a bactericidal agent, follow concentration dependent killing kinetics.

  • Aminoglycosides exert concentration dependent bactericidal action and a long as well as concentration dependent post-antibiotic effect. Therefore higher plasma concentrations attained after the single daily dose will be equally or more effective than the divided doses.
  • With the single daily dose, the plasma concentration will remain subthreshold for ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity for a longer period each day allowing washout of the drug from the endolymph and the renal cortex.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 796.

questions.text: A 65 yr old woman has returned from a vacation abroad from traveller's diarrhoea. A pathogenic gram negative bacilli is suspected. Which drug is most likely to be effective in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ofloxacin

This FQ is somewhat less active than ciprofloxacin against gram-negative bacteria, but equally or more potent against Strep. pyogenes and other gram-positive cocci and certain anaerobes. Good activity against Chlamydia and Mycoplasma has been noted.

It is an alternative drug for nonspecific urethritis, cervicitis and atypical pneumonia caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. It also inhibits M.

tuberculosis; can be used in resistant cases of TB. High activity is exhibited against M. leprae and it is being used in alternative multidrug therapy regimens.

Ofloxacin is comparable to ciprofloxacin in the therapy of systemic and mixed infections. It is suitable for chronic bronchitis and other respiratory or ENT infections as well as for chlamydia urethritis as an alternative drug. Inhibition of theophylline metabolism is less marked.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 763-764.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is/are examples of drug repositioning?
questions.solution:
The process of finding new uses of existing drugs outside scope of the original indication is variously referred as drug repositioning, redirecting, repurposing and reprofiling.

Amphotericin B

Original indication: Fungal infections

New indication: Leishmaniasis

Methotrexate:

Original indication: Cancer

New indication: Psoriasis, Rheumatoid arthritis

Propranolol:

Original indication: Hypertension

New indication: Migraine prophylaxis

Hydroxychloroquine

Original indication: Malaria

New indication: Rheumatoid arthritis, COVID-19

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 839-840.

questions.text: A 30 yr old man has been treated with several autonomic drugs for 4 weeks. He is now admitted with signs of drug toxicity. Which of the following signs would distinguish between an overdose of ganglion blocker versus a muscarinic blocker?
questions.solution:
Neither ganglion blockers nor muscarinic blockers cause miosis; they cause mydriasis. Both classes of cholinoceptor blockers increase resting heart rate and cause cycloplegia, because these are determined largely by parasympathetic tone. Similarly, both can cause dry skin, since this requires cholinergic transmission. Postural hypotension, on the other hand, is a sign of sympathetic blockade, which would occur with ganglion blockers but not muscarinic blockers

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 135.

questions.text: A patient of schizophrenia was started on haloperidol. Next day, he presented with uprolling of eyes. Complete neurological examination revealed no spasticity or any other abnormalities. Visual acuity and ophthalmoscopy findings are normal. Most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Acute muscular dystonias

Bizarre muscle spasms, mostly involving linguo-facial muscles-grimacing, tongue thrusting, torticollis, locked jaw; occurs within a few hours of a single dose or at the most in the first week of therapy. It is more common in children below 10 years and in girls, particularly after parenteral administration; overall incidence is 2%. It lasts for one to few hours and then resolves spontaneously.

One of the central anticholinergics, promethazine or hydroxyzine injected i.m. clears the reaction within 10-15 min.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 471.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presented to the emergency department with tachycardia, shortness of breath, and chest pain. She had had shortness of breath and diarrhea for the last 2 d and was sweating and anxious. A relative reported that the patient had run out of methimazole 2 wk earlier. A TSH measurement revealed a value of <0.01 mIU/L (normal 0.4-4.0 mIU/L). The diagnosis of thyroid storm was made. Which of the following is a drug that is a useful adjuvant in the treatment of thyroid storm?
questions.solution:
In thyroid storm, β blockers such as propranolol are useful in controlling the tachycardia and other cardiac abnormalities, and propranolol also inhibits peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 278.

choices.text: An 18-year-old woman who took an overdose of cocaine and now has a blood pressure of 190/110 mm Hg
A 27-year-old woman with severe diarrhea caused by a flare in her inflammatory bowel disease
A 57-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes who has not taken her glyburide for the last 3 d
A 62-year-old man with severe bradycardia and hypotension resulting from ingestion of an overdose of atenolol

questions.text: Which of the following patients is most likely to be treated with intravenous glucagon?
questions.solution:
Glucagon acts through cardiac glucagon receptors to stimulate the rate and force of contraction of the heart. Because this bypasses cardiac β adrenoceptors, glucagon is useful in the treatment of β-blocker-induced cardiac depression.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 304.

questions.text: PJ is a 4.5-year-old boy. At his checkup, the pediatrician notices cutaneous xanthomas and orders a lipid panel. Repeated measures confirm that the patient's serum cholesterol levels are high (936 mg/dL). Further testing confirms a diagnosis of homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia. Which of the following interventions will be least effective in this patient?
questions.solution:
Homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia is caused by mutations leading to dysfunctional LDL receptors incapable of taking up LDL from the bloodstream. Lomitapide and mipomersen are specifically indicated for patients with familial hypercholesterolemia. Reductase inhibitors such as atorvastatin rely on functional LDL receptors to achieve a LDL-lowering effect and thus will not work in patients with homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia.

Reference: Goodman and Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no. 743-744.

choices.text: Competitively blocks angiotensin II at its receptor
Decreases calcium efflux from skeletal muscle
Decreases renin concentration in the blood
Decreases calcium influx into smooth muscle

questions.text: Which one of the following is characteristic of nifedipine treatment in patients with essential hypertension?
questions.solution:
Nifedipine is a prototype L-type calcium channel blocker and lowers blood pressure by reducing calcium influx into vascular smooth muscle. It has no effect on angiotensin-converting enzyme. Calcium efflux from skeletal muscle cells does not involve the L-type Ca channel. The plasma renin level may increase as a result of the compensatory response to reduced blood pressure. Calcium channel blockers have negligible effects on urine calcium.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 595.

questions.text: Drug that does not bind to alpha 1 acid glycoprotein
questions.solution: Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 26.

choices.text: Does not inhibit hepatic microsomal enzymes
Eradicate mycoplasma infections in a single dose

questions.text: Advantage of clarithromycin over erythromycin is:
questions.solution:
Clarithromycin can be administered less frequently than erythromycin, but it is not effective in single doses against susceptible organisms. Organisms resistant to erythromycin, including pneumococci and methicillin-resistant staphylococci, are also resistant to other macrolides. Drug interactions have occurred with clarithromycin through its ability to inhibit cytochrome P450. Clarithromycin is more active than erythromycin against M avium complex, T gondii, and H pylori.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 803-804.

questions.text: Sulfonamides causes all of the following ADR's Except:
questions.solution:
ADR of sulfonamides:

Hemolytic anemia

Hypersensitivity

Kernicterus

Kidney (Crystalluria, Hematuria)

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 757.

choices.text: Phase IIa is a pilot clinical (Proof of concept) trial
Phase IIb is also called as early pivotal well controlled trial
Phase IIIa is a trial which is conducted prior to regulatory submission of New drug application
Phase IIIb is a trial conducted after drug approval and launch

questions.text: Which of the following statements about clinical trials is not true:
questions.solution:
Purpose of Phase II:

  • Safety in patients
  • Early efficacy
  • To determine dose/concentration - response relationship
  • Pharmacokinetics
  • Optimum dose finding

Subset of phase II:

IIa - Pilot (Proof of concept) clinical trial

IIb - Well controlled early pivotal clinical trial (Represents most rigorous demonstration of medicine's efficacy

Purpose of Phase III:

  • Benefit - risk relationship
  • Compare different approaches for a condition
  • Compare symptoms and quality of life parameters

Subset of phase III:

IIIa - Trial conducted after efficacy of drug is established but before submission of New Drug Application (NDA)

IIIb - Trial conducted after NDA but before approval and launch.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 91.

questions.text: Action of adrenaline on which of the following receptors is not required in treatment of anaphylactic shock?
questions.solution:
Alpha 1 → Vasoconstriction → Increase in diastolic BP

Beta 1 → Cardiac stimulation → Increase in systolic BP

Beta 2 → Bronchodilation → Reverse bronchoconstriction

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 150.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-psychotic drug is available as depot injection?
questions.solution: Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 467.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with insomnia and fears she may have 'something wrong with her heart. 'She describes' her heart jumping out of her chest.' She feels healthy otherwise and reports she has lots of energy. Lab tests confirm hyperthyroidism. Which of the following is a drug that produces a permanent reduction in thyroid activity?
questions.solution:
Propylthiouracil and, to a much lesser extent, methimazole inhibit peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. Thyroglobulin is not a drug. Radioactive iodine is the only medical therapy that produces a permanent reduction of thyroid activity. Anions such as thiocyanate (SCN–) and perchlorate (ClO4–) block the uptake of iodide by the thyroid gland through competitive inhibition of the iodide transporter. Their effectiveness is unpredictable and ClO4– can cause aplastic anemia, so these drugs are rarely used.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 278.

choices.text: Decrease the absorption of calcium from bone
Increase the absorption of calcium from the gastrointestinal Tract

questions.text: The active metabolites of vitamin D act through a nuclear receptor to produce which of the following effects?
questions.solution:
The active metabolites of vitamin D increase serum calcium and phosphate by promoting calcium and phosphate uptake from the gastrointestinal tract, increasing bone resorption, and decreasing renal excretion of both electrolytes. They inhibit, rather than stimulate, PTH formation.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 366-367.

questions.text: After being counseled about lifestyle and dietary changes, the patient was started on atorvastatin. During his treatment with atorvastatin, it is important to routinely monitor serum concentrations of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The 2 primary adverse effects of the HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors are hepatotoxicity and myopathy. Patients taking these drugs should have liver function tests performed before starting therapy, and at regular intervals as needed during therapy. Serum concentrations of alanine and aspartate aminotransferase are used as markers of hepatocellular toxicity.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 686.

choices.text: Both increase sympathetic outflow from the CNS

questions.text: Comparison of prazosin with atenolol shows that
questions.solution:
Atenolol, but not prazosin, may decrease heart rate. Prazosin-but not atenolol-may increase cardiac output, a compensatory effect. Prazosin may increase renin output (a compensatory response), but β blockers inhibit its release by the kidney. By reducing blood pressure, both may increase central sympathetic outflow (a compensatory response).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 155-158.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the emergency department with severe chest pain. ECG reveals ventricular tachycardia with occasional normal sinus beats, and ST-segment changes suggestive of ischemia. A diagnosis of myocardial infarction is made, and the man is admitted to the cardiac intensive care unit. His arrhythmia should be treated immediately with
questions.solution:
Lidocaine has limited applications as an antiarrhythmic drug, but emergency treatment of myocardial infarction arrhythmias is one of the most important. Lidocaine is also useful in digoxin-induced arrhythmias. After recovery from the acute phase of a myocardial infarction, β blockers are used for 2 yr or more to prevent sudden death arrhythmias.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 575-576.

questions.text: A 57 yr old chronic alcoholic develops hepatic encephalopathy. In an attempt to decrease his ammonia levels, you decide to sterilize his intestine. Which antibiotic can be given to accomplish this?
questions.solution:
Neomycin is an aminoglycoside with high systemic toxicity (Nephrotoxicity).

Given per orally, it has got very poor absorption due to its ionized nature.

Neomycin is given per orally for treatment of hepatic coma and for pre operative gut sterilization

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 799.

questions.text:
Folic acid metabolism is inhibited by:
1. Sulfonamides
2. Nitrous oxide
3. Methotrexate
4. Trimethoprim
5. 5-Flucytosine
questions.solution:
Mechanism of action of Sulfonamides

Many bacteria synthesize their own folic acid(FA) of which paminobenzoic acid(PABA) is a constituent and is taken up from the medium. Woods and Fildes(1940) proposed the hypothesis that sulfonamides, being structural analogues of PABA, inhibit bacterial folate synthase, so that FA is not formed and a number of essential metabolic reactions suffer.

Sulfonamides competitively inhibit the union of PABA with pteridine residue to form dihydropteroic acid which conjugates with glutamic acid to produce dihydrofolic acid.

Moreover, being chemically similar to PABA, the sulfonamide may itself get incorporated to form an altered folate which is metabolically injurious.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 756-921.

questions.text: The detailed report of Serous adverse event (SAE) must be submitted to the CDSCO by the investigators/sponsors within how many calendar days of the occurrence of SAE
questions.solution:
Detailed report:

Submitted by investigators / Sponsors to the CDSCO within 14 calendar days of occurrence of SAE

Submitted by the IEC to the CDSCO within 30 calendar days of occurrence of SAE.

Reference: New Drugs and Clinical Trials rules, 2019, Page no. 163.

questions.text: Which of the following combinations will show vasomotor reversal of Dale?
questions.solution:
Vasomotor reversal of Dale

The α blockers abolish the pressor action of Adr(injected i.v. in animals), which then produces only fall in BP due to β2 mediated vasodilatation. This was first demonstrated by Sir HH Dale(1913) and is called vasomotor reversal of Dale. Pressor and other actions of selective α agonists(phenylephrine) are suppressed.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 153-154.

questions.text: The position of beta carboline activity on GABA BZD Binding site in below graph is
questions.solution: Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 430.

questions.text: Which of the following is a sign or symptom that would be expected to occur in the event of chronic overdose with exogenous T4?
questions.solution:
In hyperthyroidism, the metabolic rate increases, and even though there is increased appetite, weight loss often occurs. The other choices are symptoms seen in hypothyroidism.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 270.

questions.text: A 58-year-old postmenopausal woman was sent for dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry to evaluate the bone mineral density of her lumbar spine, femoral neck, and total hip. The test results revealed significantly low bone mineral density in all sites. Chronic use of which of the following medications is most likely to have contributed to this woman's osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Long-term therapy with glucocorticoids such as prednisone is associated with a reduction in bone mineral density and an increased risk of fractures. The other drugs are not known to have significant effects on bone or serum calcium.

Osteoporosis: especially involving vertebrae and other flat spongy bones. Compression fractures of vertebrae and spontaneous fracture of long bones can occur, especially in the elderly. Radiological evidence of osteoporosis is an indication for withdrawal of corticoid therapy.

Corticosteroid induced osteoporosis can be prevented/arrested to some extent by calcium supplements + vit D, but bisphosphonates are the most effective drugs in this regard.

Avascular necrosis of head of femur, humerous or knee joint is an occasional abrupt onset complication of high dose corticosteroid therapy.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 318

questions.text: Consumption of alcohol is associated with which of the following changes in serum lipid concentrations?
questions.solution:
Chronic ethanol ingestion can increase serum concentrations of VLDL and triglycerides. This is one of the factors that places patients with alcoholism at risk of pancreatitis. Chronic ethanol ingestion also has the possibly beneficial effect of raising, not decreasing, serum HDL concentrations.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 420

choices.text: Dizziness due to reduced cardiac force of contraction

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a complaint of severe chest pain when he walks uphill to his home in cold weather. The pain disappears when he rests. After evaluation and discussion of treatment options, a decision is made to treat him with nitroglycerin. In advising the patient about the adverse effects he may notice, you point out that nitroglycerin in moderate doses often produces certain symptoms. Which of the following effects might occur due to the mechanism listed?
questions.solution:
The nitrates relax many types of smooth muscle, but the effect on motility in the colon is insignificant. Nitroglycerin causes hypotension as a result of arterial and venous dilation. Dilation of arteries in the meninges has no effect on central nervous system function but does cause headache.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 587

questions.text:
A drug was tested in the electrophysiology laboratory to determine its effects on the cardiac action potential in normal ventricular cells. The results are shown in the diagram.


Which of the following agent does this drug most resemble?
questions.solution:
The drug effect shown in the diagram includes slowing of the upstroke of the AP but no significant change in repolarization or AP duration. This is most typical of group 1C drugs.

Reference: Goodman and Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no. 688

choices.text: Decrease the dose to daily total of 200 mg
Discontinue amikacin and start on gentamicin
Decrease the dose to 180 mg every 8 h

questions.text: A 72 kg patient with creatinine clearance of 80 mL/min has a Gram -ve infection. Amikacin is administered intramuscularly at a dose of 5 mg/kg every 8 hrs and the patient begins to respond. After 2 days, creatinine clearance declines to 40 mL/min. Assuming that no information is available about amikacin plasma levels, what would be the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Monitoring plasma drug levels is important when aminoglycosides are used. In this case, the patient seems to be improving, so a decrease of the amikacin dose in proportion to decreased creatinine clearance is most appropriate. Because creatinine clearance is only one half of the starting value, a dose reduction should be made to one half of that given initially.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 796

questions.text: Supplementary folinic acid may prevent anemia in folate deficiency patients who use the following drug which is a weak base:
questions.solution:
Trimethoprim is the only weak base listed (fluoroquinolones and sulfonamides are acidic compounds), and its high lipid solubility at blood pH allows penetration of the drug into prostatic and vaginal fluid to reach levels similar to those in plasma. Leukopenia and thrombocytopenia may occur in folate deficiency when the drug is used alone or in combination with sulfamethoxazole. Fluoroquinolones and linezolid do not exacerbate symptoms of folic acid deficiency.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 757-758.

questions.text: Three formulations: formulation A, formulation B and formulation C of a drug containing the same amount were given orally. Which of following the formulation in the graph have lower oral bioavailability?
questions.solution:
• Plasma concentration-time curves depicting bioavailability differences between three preparations of a drug containing the same amount is shown in graph
  • Points to note from the graph
    • Formulation B is more slowly absorbed than A
    • Formulation B and A are absorbed to the same extent
      • BECAUSE area under the curve same FOR both A and B
    • Even B is equally bioavailable as A but it is not producing therapeutic effect
    • C is absorbed to a lesser extent compared to A and B but not reaching therapeutic concentration
    • C has lower bioavailability

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 22

questions.text: The action of dopamine at a dose of 1-2mcg/kg/min dose is?
questions.solution:
D1 → Renal vasodilation → Diuresis → Used in oliguria

Beta 1 → Inotropic effect → CHF

Alpha 1 Vasoconstriction → Shock

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 146.

questions.text:
A Patient on anti-parkinsonian drug developed features shown in the image.


Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
The image shown is that of livedo reticularis caused by Amantadine

  • Amantadine
    • Antiviral drug for prophylaxis of influenza A2 and used in parkinsonism
    • Other ADRs: insomnia, restlessness, confusion, nightmares, anticholinergic
  • Pergolide and Cabergoline use associated with valvular heart disease

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 460.

questions.text: Glucocorticoids have proved useful in the treatment of which of the following medical conditions?
questions.solution:
Glucocorticoids are used in combination with other antiemetics to prevent chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, which are commonly associated with anticancer drugs.

Corticosteroids(e.g. dexamethasone 8-20 mg i.v. before chemotherapy) can partly alleviate nausea and vomiting due to moderately emetogenic chemotherapy, but are more often employed to augment the efficacy of other primary antiemetic drugs like metoclopramide and ondansetron against highly emetogenic regimens.

Corticosteroids enhance efficacy against both acute and delayed emesis. Dexamethasone 8 mg/day oral from 2-5th day of chemotherapy helps to alleviate delayed vomiting. The basis of the effect is not known; appears to be due to their anti-inflammatory action. They also serve to reduce certain side effects of the primary antiemetic.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 718.

choices.text: Activating a steroid receptor that inhibits expression of the PTH gene
Activating the calcium-sensing receptor in parathyroid cells
Activating transporters in the GI tract that are involved in calcium absorption
Inducing the liver enzyme that converts vitamin D3 to 25-hydroxyvitamin D3

questions.text: In the treatment of patients with secondary hyperparathyroidism due to chronic kidney disease, cinacalcet is an alternative to vitamin D-based drugs. Cinacalcet lowers PTH by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Cinacalcet is a member of a novel class of drugs that activate the calcium-sensing receptor in parathyroid cells. When this receptor is activated by cinacalcet or free ionized calcium, it activates a signaling pathway that suppresses PTH synthesis and release.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 364-365.

questions.text: Which of the following is a major toxicity associated with gemfibrozil therapy?
questions.solution:
A major toxicity of the fibrates is increased risk of gallstone formation, which may be due to enhanced biliary excretion of cholesterol.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 687.

choices.text: Beta blockers and nitrates on end-diastolic cardiac size
Beta blockers and nitrates on heart rate
Beta blockers and nitrates on venous tone
Calcium channel blockers and β blockers on cardiac force

questions.text: When nitrates are used in combination with other drugs for the treatment of angina, which one of the following combinations results in additive effects on the variable specified?
questions.solution:
The effects of β blockers (or calcium channel blockers) and nitrates on heart size, force, venous tone, and heart rate are opposite. The effects of β blockers and calcium channel blockers on the variables specified here are the same.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 590-591.

choices.text: It has a high affinity for angiotensin II receptors
It promotes increased peripheral vascular resistance
It decreases cardiac output and increases afterload
It causes venodilation and induces natriuresis

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman is diagnosed with congestive heart failure (CHF). You prescribe captopril, a medication proven to reduce her mortality. This agent delivers several benefits to patients with CHF. Which of the following effects is caused by this drug?
questions.solution:
Angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors cause venodilation and induce natriuresis, thereby reducing preload. A high affinity for angiotensin II receptors represents the mechanism of action of angiotensin-receptor blockers. ACE inhibitors counteract increased peripheral resistance, increase cardiac output, and decrease afterload.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 530-531.

questions.text: A 12 yr old boy presents with rash on palms and sole of his feet following a bite with a tick. His weil-Felix test is positive suggesting Rocky mountain spotted fever. Which of the following drugs should be given?
questions.solution:
Doxycycline, a tetracycline (30S ribosome inhibitor), is the antibiotic of choice to treat Rocky Mountain spotted fever, a rickettsial disease. Streptomycin can be used to treat plague and brucellosis. Bacitracin is only used topically. Ciprofloxacin can be used to treat anthrax, and erythromycin is the most effective drug for the treatment of Legionnaires

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 788.

questions.text: Which adverse effect is most common with sulphonamides?
questions.solution:
The most common adverse effect of the sulfonamides is a skin rash caused by hypersensitivity. Neurologic dysfunction and hematuria occur less frequently. Sulfonamides are usually avoided in the third trimester of pregnancy or in neonates, so kernicterus is rare. Fanconi's syndrome is associated with the use of outdated tetracyclines

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no. 757.
